Yes, these are ways how one can shoot oneself in the foot via setting LDFLAGS,
but my understanding of the R design of these things is that it is
intentionally the responsibility of the user/the person building R - to use
directories that are safe, to use linker flags that are as portable as needed
for this task, etc.

*[Bug 15444] Script file save path lost*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15444>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #4 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I've fixed this in R-devel - changed to the previous behavior.

The restored behavior is that the start location for the "Save script as"
dialog is the directory where the file is currently located. Consequently, the
current file name is also shown in the dialog, which I believe is acceptable
behavior (after all Notepad does this too, and the user is asked before
overwriting the file).

The behavior change was in a different commit from the one discussed above.
Originally, and now again, the dialog gets as a default value the current full
path to the file being edited. In that situation, Windows would normally use
the directory from that path to start from. The change in the meantime was that
the dialog got an empty string as the default value, then it would use the
current working directory of the process.

I wrote "normally", because this is not the full truth. From Windows 7, which
was I assume used already also when this report was filed, Windows would
sometimes ignore the default value provided, but use the last directory
selected in dialogs (aka most-recently used, not only in "Save script as", but
also other dialogs). Windows would do this when the initial directory provided
is the same as it was provided the first time the application, once installed,
used that dialog bog. The value is saved in the registry under
ComDlg32\FirstFolder. This is why this issue is very hard to debug - sometimes
one gets the most recently used folder, depending on what was the first
directory ever selected by the application. More details can be found at

<https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/commdlg/ns-commdlg-openfilenamea>
